merlin.0:
Hello there! 
Welcome to a special quantum world!

merlin.1: I am Merlin. I am here to explain this world.

merlin.2: As you may have noticed, you can use the arrow keys or the 'A' and 'D' keys to move left and right.

merlin.3: You can use the space bar or 'W' to jump and use 'G' to interact.

merlin.4: On the top left of the screen you can see how many lives you have. Anytime you get hit by an enemy or fall, you will lose a heart and return to the previous checkpoint. Isn't that convenient?

merlin.5: Warning: Jumping on top of enemies will NOT defeat them. You must avoid all contact with enemies.

merlin.6: If you lose all your hearts, the level will end. You can then choose to restart from the beginning.

merlin.7: Next to the hearts you can see your coins collected. They get reset once you lose all your lives. Every 3 coins you collect will increase the number of lives.

merlin.8: You can use the escape key ('ESC') to pause the game.

merlin.9: Now proceed and find the first checkpoint!

merlin2.0:
Hello there! 
I see that you have found the checkpoint.

merlin2.1: Now that you are familiar with some of the basic mechanics, let's introduce some more.

merlin2.2: At the top of your screen, next to the number of coins, is the probability of you being in state 0 or state 1.

merlin2.3: Here, state 1 means the upper layer (the one you are on right now) and state 0 is the lower layer. Sometimes to avoid certain obstacles you would need to transition between layers.

merlin2.4: Next to the probabilities is a sphere called the Bloch Sphere. It is a representation of your current state. Rotations on this sphere's surface allow you to change your state.

merlin2.5:
The sphere has three axes: X, Y, and Z. 
These are NOT related to the 2D directions in the game world.

merlin2.6: Next to the sphere are angles to help you control your state more precisely. Theta is the angle from the Z axis and phi is the angle from the X axis.

merlin2.7:
You can rotate about the X, Y or Z axis by pressing the 'X', 'Y' or 'Z' keys. 
X and Y rotations will change your probabilities between state 0 and state 1. 
Z rotations will not change these probabilities, but they have other uses that you will discover later.

merlin2.8: These rotations will not work if you stand too close to interactable objects like me :)

merlin2.9: Colliding with objects like coins, standing on checkpoints, or getting hit by enemies will 'measure' you along the Z axis.

merlin2.10:
Measurement is like a probabilistic reset: you will instantly collapse to either state 0 or state 1 based on the probabilities shown on the left of the Bloch sphere. 
You will not be in both states anymore.

merlin2.11: You can also measure yourself by pressing 'M'. This can be useful if you want to reset your state when there is nothing nearby to interact with.

merlin2.12: Here, walls and the ground do not measure you. Keep in mind that you may get stuck against a wall even if you have only a 0.1 probability in that layer, so check your probabilities and consider measuring yourself.

merlin2.13: Your goal is to use this quantum mechanic to navigate between layers, avoid enemies, collect coins and reach the end of the level.

merlin2.14: Now venture forth and explore this world!

merlin3.0:
Hello there! 
I see that you are getting a hang of being in superposition and getting measured.

merlin3.1: Superposition? Ah I didn't explain it earlier. The states 0 and 1 are what we see in the 'classical' world, think bits in a computer.

merlin3.2: While you were doing rotations, you were neither in state 0 nor state 1 but in a combination of both states with a certain probability of being in each.

merlin3.3: That is what we mean by being in superposition.

merlin3.4: Anyways, in front of you is a new mechanic: a superposition check zone.

merlin3.5: These don't exist in the real world but they are here to force you to master the X, Y and Z rotations :)

merlin3.6: To pass through safely, you need to use the 'X', 'Y', and 'Z' keys to rotate your state until your theta and phi angles match the target values shown next to the check zone.

merlin3.7:
When the zone turns green, you're close enough to pass through safely! 
The fidelity shows how close your state was to the target.

merlin3.8: Don't worry, you don't have to match the angles exactly, just get close enough for the zone to turn green.

merlin3.9: Well, now I will see you next at the end of the level.

merlin4.0:
Hello there! 
You have made it to the end of this level.

merlin4.1: By touching the flag you can end the level. Now, level 1 has been unlocked in the level select screen.

merlin4.2: Level 1 introduces a new game mechanic.

merlin4.3: I will appear again to explain new mechanics. See you again!

merlin-lvl1-0.1:
Now it is time for the new game mechanic... 
Circuit Puzzles!

merlin-lvl1-0.2: To continue forward you have to solve the circuit. On the right there are 2 wires, one above and one below. These represent 2 qubits.

merlin-lvl1-0.3: You may be familiar with |0> and |1> from the hud, but that is for a single qubit. If we have 2 qubits, both in state 0, we write them as |0>|0> or |00>.

merlin-lvl1-0.4: Your goal is to create the target state shown in text below the wires. To help you with this, the current state is also shown.

merlin-lvl1-0.5: In the texts for current and target state, the upper wire refers to the first(red) number and the lower wire refers to the second(green) number inside |>. The 'amplitude' of each state is given after the state for example: To represent |01>, |0> in top qubit and |1> in bottom qubit, it would show |00>: 0.0 |01>: 1.0 |10>: 0.0 |11>: 0.0.

merlin-lvl1-0.6: The amplitudes of the states that you change will turn yellow. If your current state matches the target state, the amplitudes will turn green.

merlin-lvl1-0.7: The circles on the ground with a letter in them are gates. We use these to change the state of the qubits.

merlin-lvl1-0.8: The X gate changes |0> to |1> and changes |1> to |0>. This is the same as the 'X' key rotation you have been doing for 180 degrees.

merlin-lvl1-0.9: Keep in mind none of these gates actually change your superposition. They affect the state of the qubits in the wire only.

merlin-lvl1-0.10: You need to stand near the gates, press 'G' to interact and pick up the gate. If you pick up a gate, it will be shown in the HUD.

merlin-lvl1-0.11: After picking up the gate, you need to add it to the circuit. The green blocks with 'Add' written above them will insert the gates to the puzzle.

merlin-lvl1-0.12: The bottom ones add to the bottom wire and the top ones add to the top wire. The Add blocks on the left of the wire will always insert the gate to the beginning of the circuit, and the Add blocks on the right will add it to the end of the circuit.

merlin-lvl1-0.13: Similarly, the 'Del' blocks in red, remove gates from either the left or right of the respective wire.

merlin-lvl1-0.14: To run the circuit there is the 'Run' block in purple and there is a 'Reset' block in orange to reset the entire circuit.

merlin-lvl1-0.15: To interact with any of these blocks, stand close/on them and press 'G'. Beware that if you are too close to any of the blocks or gates, you may not be able to go in superposition.

merlin-lvl1-0.16: The gates and blocks will also measure you and collapse your superposition.

merlin-lvl1-0.17: So that you don't have to keep rememebering, whenever you talk with me further on in this level, I will explain the required gates for the level.

merlin-lvl1-0.18: Remember: The X gate changes |0> to |1> and changes |1> to |0>. This is the same as the 'X' key rotation you have been doing for 180 degrees.

merlin-lvl1-2.0:
Hello there! 
You have managed to pass the first 2 puzzles!

merlin-lvl1-2.1: As you may have noticed, only the gate which is necessary is present in the puzzle. Now, you will be encountering circuits which require 2 gates to be applied. Pay close attention to the target state!

merlin-lvl1-2.2: I will now be explaining circuit puzzles, including the gates required to solve the puzzle.

merlin-lvl1-2.3: To continue forward you have to solve the circuit. On the right there are 2 wires, one above and one below. These represent 2 qubits.

merlin-lvl1-2.4: Your goal is to create the target state shown in text below the wires. To help you with this, the current state is also shown.

merlin-lvl1-2.5: In the texts for current and target state, the upper wire refers to the first(red) number and the lower wire refers to the second(green) number inside |>. merlin-lvl1-2.6: The amplitudes of the states that you change will turn yellow. If your current state matches the target state, the amplitudes will turn green.

merlin-lvl1-2.7: The Z gate does nothing to |0> (changes |0> to |0>) and changes |1> to -|1>. This is the same as the 'Z' key rotation for 180 degrees.

merlin-lvl1-2.8: The H(Hadamard) gate changes |0> to 0.71|0> + 0.71|1> and changes |1> to 0.71|0> - 0.71|1>.

Hello there! 
You have managed to pass the first 3 puzzles!

merlin-lvl1-3.1: Pay close attention to the target state!

merlin-lvl1-3.2: I will now be explaining circuit puzzles, including the gates required to solve the puzzle.

merlin-lvl1-3.4: Your goal is to create the target state shown in text below the wires. To help you with this, the current state is also shown.

merlin-lvl1-3.5: In the texts for current and target state, the upper wire refers to the first(red) number and the lower wire refers to the second(green) number inside |>. The 'amplitude' of each state is given after the state for example: To represent |01>, |0> in top qubit and |1> in bottom qubit, it would show |00>: 0.0 |01>: 1.0 |10>: 0.0 |11>: 0.0.

merlin-lvl1-3.6: The amplitudes of the states that you change will turn yellow. If your current state matches the target state, the amplitudes will turn green.

merlin-lvl1-3.7: The Y gate changes |0> to i|1> and changes |1> to -i|0>. This is the same as the 'Y' key rotation you have been doing for 180 degrees. As you can see, this is similar to X but we get some imaginary number in front of the state.

merlin-lvl1-3.8: The H(Hadamard) gate changes |0> to 0.71|0> + 0.71|1> and changes |1> to 0.71|0> - 0.71|1>.

merlin-lvl1-4.0:
Hello there! 
You have now finished 4 puzzles! How were they?

merlin-lvl1-4.1: To give you a break, we are showing something new :)

merlin-lvl1-4.2: As you can see, there is quite a large gap that cannot be crossed.

merlin-lvl1-4.3: Also at the end is a superposition check zone.

merlin-lvl1-4.4: Your task is to be in that state and then teleport to that side.

merlin-lvl1-4.5: Well, technically, transferring your state to another qubit, but good enough! To do this, create the state that you need to be in, and press 'G' at the single orange block on the ground in the lower layer.

merlin-lvl1-4.6: This will then execute the Quantum Teleportation circuit shown on the wires on the right, above the gap. You are represented by the top qubit.

merlin-lvl1-4.7:
This circuit is used to transfer your state to the other qubit.
Also, it has a hint for the final puzzle!

merlin-lvl1-4.8: Well, I will see you before the next puzzle to repeat the information about the puzzle. Enjoy!

merlin-lvl1-4.9: Also, don't worry about what happens to the original qubit :)

merlin-lvl1-5.1: The final puzzle will make you create the famous Bell state, well one of them. This is an example of an entangled state, more of which you will encounter in level 2.

merlin-lvl1-5.2: I will now be explaining circuit puzzles, including the gates required to solve the puzzle.

merlin-lvl1-5.3: To continue forward you have to solve the circuit. On the right there are 2 wires, one above and one below. These represent 2 qubits.

merlin-lvl1-5.4: Your goal is to create the target state shown in text below the wires. To help you with this, the current state is also shown.

merlin-lvl1-5.5: In the texts for current and target state, the upper wire refers to the first(red) number and the lower wire refers to the second(green) number inside |>. The 'amplitude' of each state is given after the state for example: To represent |01>, |0> in top qubit and |1> in bottom qubit, it would show |00>: 0.0 |01>: 1.0 |10>: 0.0 |11>: 0.0.

merlin-lvl1-5.6: The amplitudes of the states that you change will turn yellow. If your current state matches the target state, the amplitudes will turn green.

merlin-lvl1-5.7: The H(Hadamard) gate changes |0> to 0.71|0> + 0.71|1> and changes |1> to 0.71|0> - 0.71|1>.

merlin-lvl1-5.8: The C(CNOT) gate is a 2 qubit gate. You have a control qubit and a target qubit. If the control qubit is in state |0>, it does not do anything to the target qubit. If the control qubit is in the state |1>, it performs an X gate on the target qubit, i.e., makes |0> to |1> and |1> to |0>

merlin-lvl1-5.9: Basically, it is a conditional NOT gate.

merlin-lvl1-5.10: Now go forth and tackle the final puzzle!

merlin-lvl1-6.0:
Hello there! 
You have reached the end of this level.

merlin-lvl1-6.1: By touching the flag you can end the level. Now, level 2 have been unlocked in the level select screen which introduces a new game mechanic.

merlin-lvl2-0.0:
Hello there! 
I see you have come quite far in this game.

merlin-lvl2-0.1:
I would congratulate you, but this isn't over yet. 
Things are about to get... spooky.

merlin-lvl2-0.2:
See that purple gem ahead? That's no ordinary crystal. 
The gem itself has a state: when it's on the lower layer, it's in state 0, and when it's on the upper layer, it's in state 1.

merlin-lvl2-0.3: Follow the superposition check zone and stay in that state. Then, stand on the gem and press 'C' to perform a CNOT gate.

merlin-lvl2-0.4: When you do, you will become linked with the gem in mysterious ways.

merlin-lvl2-0.5:
Remember CNOT? It's a Controlled-NOT operation. 
If the control qubit is in state 1, it flips the target qubit. If the control is 0, nothing happens to the target.

merlin-lvl2-0.6:
Here's what's important: YOU are always the control qubit, and the gem is always the target. 
So if you're on the upper layer (state 1), the CNOT will flip the gem's layer!

merlin-lvl2-0.7:
When you perform CNOT, you will become entangled with the gem. 
In quantum terms, your superposition becomes the first qubit, and the gem becomes the second qubit.

merlin-lvl2-0.8: Your HUD will change to show four probabilities: 00 (both on lower layer), 01 (you on lower, gem on upper), 10 (you on upper, gem on lower), and 11 (both on upper layer).

merlin-lvl2-0.9: Whenever you get measured, both you and the gem collapse together to one of these four states. If you both end up on the same layer (00 or 11), you will physically carry the gem with you (non-quantumly).

merlin-lvl2-0.10: If you're carrying the gem and try to enter superposition again, the gem drops from your hands. This doesn't happen in the real world—it's just a game mechanic to make you experiment more :)

merlin-lvl2-0.11: While entangled, you can still use your X, Y, and Z rotations. These only affect your part of the entangled state without breaking the connection, allowing you to move from 00 to 10 and 01 to 11, and vice versa.

merlin-lvl2-0.12: After carrying the gem (post-measurement to 00 or 11), approach the yellow blocks and press 'G', which will remove some blocking obstacles that are present on both layers.

merlin-lvl2-0.13:
IMPORTANT: Check your superposition state BEFORE you entangle! 
If you're only in state 0 when you entangle, you can only create 00 and 10 states. You'll never be able to reach 01 or 11 without measuring first and starting over.

merlin-lvl2-0.14: Now go ahead, try it out! Entangle with the gem and explore what happens. If you fail, you can always entangle again.

merlin-lvl2-1.0:
Hello there! 
It looks like you are starting to get familiar with the world of entanglement.

merlin-lvl2-1.1:
So far, entanglement was your friend — it helped you unlock doors to paths unexplored. 
Now, let's see how you do when it acts as your enemy!

merlin-lvl2-1.2:
Do you see the giant squirrel ahead? Walk too close to it, and it will kill you! 
But this is an entanglable enemy: if you are in the shaded region around it, you can entangle with it using 'C'.

merlin-lvl2-1.3: Remember, CNOT here has you as the control and the enemy the target. If you're on the upper layer (state 1), the enemy will flip layers when you entangle.

merlin-lvl2-1.4: The rules of entanglement are the same, but beware! When measurement happens, WHERE the enemy spawns depends on the outcome:

merlin-lvl2-1.5:
If you collapse to 00 or 11 (same layer), the enemy will spawn where you stand! 
But if you collapse to 01 or 10 (different layers), the enemy stays at the same horizontal position as before.

merlin-lvl2-1.6: With the gem, your goal was to reach 00 or 11 to carry it. With enemies, your goal is the opposite: avoid 00 and 11 at all costs!

merlin-lvl2-1.7: At times, you may simply want to remove this enemy when it blocks your path by ensuring it spawns on a different layer.

merlin-lvl2-1.8: But at other times, you may need to place these enemies on pressure plates on the ground, which will open doors.

merlin-lvl2-1.9:
Now go onto this new challenge! 
I will see you soon with our next game mechanic.

merlin-lvl2-2.0:
Hello there! 
I see you have finally learnt how to avoid the entanglement enemy.

merlin-lvl2-2.1: Everything you have done until now was linked to measuring yourself into a particular basis state: 00, 01, 10 or 11.

merlin-lvl2-2.2:
However, now things get even more interesting.. 
Remember those superposition check zones? Imagine those, but for entangled states!
Introducing: the Entanglement-Probability Check Zone.

merlin-lvl2-2.3:
You must make specific probabilities of the 4 basis states to pass these! 
Not an easy task I must say.

merlin-lvl2-2.4: But similar to the superposition check zone, if you are in a state that is acceptable by this zone, it will turn green!

merlin-lvl2-2.5:
Thus await your final set of challenges. 
Entangle Away!

merlin-lvl2-3.0:
Hello there! 
Unbelievable that you finally made it here.

merlin-lvl2-3.1:
I fare thee well, hero of this world. 
You have conquered much more than anticipated.

merlin-lvl2-3.2: The challenge level has been unlocked in the level select screen. It contains mechanics of all the levels you have finished till now.

merlin-lvl2-3.3:
If you had fun or learnt something new, please fill the survey for our game! 
(and if you didn't, then definitely fill it) :)

merlin-lvl2-3.4: Farewell and see you again someday!

dialogue1.0: Contrary to our world, walls do not count as observers. They can stop you in both layers.

dialogue1.1: However, a cliff does count as an observer. It either observes you falling or you stay up on the ground.

dialogue2.0: There may come times when there are no observers in the neighbourhood. How then must you continue?

dialogue2.1: You can observe yourself in this case. Press 'M' to observe yourself. Do you not observe yourself in the layer you want? Rotate to increase chances.

dialogue2.2: In the HUD, you find the probability in percents a measurement puts you on top (layer 1) and the probability a measurement puts you on the bottom (layer 0).

dialogue2.3: Are you able to rotate to 100 percent on the desired layer? What about more than ninety percent? You can always try again.

dialogue3.0: These are superposition check zones. Observers like these don't exist in the real world. They can check whether you are truly in the right superposition.

dialogue3.1: As you may or may not have noticed, you can also rotate in two different directions. Where just rotating in x-direction from a pole increases theta, y- and z-direction can influence phi

dialogue3.2: Don't worry if you don't nail the theta and phi perfectly. You can be slightly off the target indicated next to the check zone.
